subject: RE: [junit] Design question: was Testing Private Methods
msgSnippet: ... This sounds like a Directed Graph, where A- B is not the same as A
messageBody:
> Except:
> 1. it can have alternate legs e.g going from A to B at
> different times. 2. have to differentiate departing itins
> from return itins
> e.g. A-B-C -> departing
> C-A -> return
> C-B-A -> return

This sounds like a Directed Graph, where A->B is not the same as A<-B
(notice the arrowhead, implying Direction). Search Google for more info
on the subject.

> etc. etc.
> To cut a long story short, assume i have put the following
> methods public class ItinBuilder {
> public void buildItins(segment[] segs);
>
> private sortByDptrDate();
> private identifyDupeSegs();
> private createUniqueItins(); // ignores duplicates
> private createAllItins(); // builds all itins based on the
> unique itins using dupes
> }
>
> So really, a "client" only needs to call buildItins(), but
> the real work happens in the private methods which therefore
> need to be tested.

So you have the requirement for a buildItinerary function. And your
investigations seem to require several other helper methods that are not
directly related to the buildItinerary function.

How about that belongs to a ItineraryUtils/ItineraryHelper class
collecting all these helper functions. They then become public on the
helper class, and the builder class can use a private instance of this
class.

<comment tone="picky">
What's wrong with typing in Itinerary, instead of just Itin?
And Departure/Duplicate/Segment?
</comment>

> Assumption:
> we'd like to keep our tests in a separate package.

As has been discussed in previous posts, you may keep your tests in the
same package, but on a parallel source tree. This will give you the
advantage of package access, with clear separation of test classes vs.
system classes (see (http://groups.yahoo.com/group/junit/message/4581)
for a nice explanatory diagram).
